ALLEGATION:
On 5/20/21, two staff members beat up youth after being angry about a late parent
phone call. Youth had injuries on their knee, foot, neck, forehead, and eye.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was received on 05/24/21 and investigated jointly with the DHHS
Specialist. The complaint alleged the following:
Youth A (14) is currently residing at Camp Highfields. Youth A is not a temporary
or permanent court ward. Staff 1 and another unknown male are staff members
at the facility. On Thursday night, Youth A got to make his family phone call.
Youth A is the last child to receive his phone call each time and it usually
happens late in the evening as all the other kids take their time before him. On
Thursday night however, instead of telling Youth A’s mother that it was already
too late for the call, the staff went and got Youth A and allowed him to continue
his call for 10 minutes. The two staff in particular, Staff 1, and another male
unknown, tend to provoke Youth A into reacting or fighting back against them.
These two staff got upset that Youth A had his call so late that night, so they beat
him up. Youth A sustained drag marks on his left knee, a cut to his right foot,
finger like bruise marks on his neck, a small skin rip on his forehead, and his left
eye was also swollen, though not enough for Youth A to still be able to see out of
it. As the nursing staff do not work on the weekends, Youth A has still not
received any medical attention for his injuries. Youth A did not go to the on-
campus school on Friday morning as his body was too sore and in pain. Youth
A’s counselor spoke with his mother and reported only that Youth A had to be
restrained Thursday night. There is concern for the physical abuse by these two
staff against Youth A that resulted in serious injuries, as well as for the lack of
medical attention received.
I interviewed Youth A at his current placement, on 05/25/21, jointly with the DHHS
Specialist. Youth A reviewed the incident by noting that it started with Supervisor 1
questioning the staff as to why Youth A was getting a phone call. This occurred
about 9:50pm, per Youth A. Youth A reported that Supervisor 1 came to the unit and
started talking under his breath about Youth A. Youth A said that Supervisor 1
grabbed him and put him on the ground. Then Staff 1 came and hit Youth A’s head
on the ground. The staff then picked him up and took him to the kitchen. Youth A
described that he was held in the restraint position with one staff on each arm and
bent forward. Once released Youth A said he sat in a chair and then went to his
bedroom. Youth A said that Supervisor 1 was in the room and Youth A touched the
door so Supervisor 1 “slammed me.” Youth A said that he was grabbed in a
headlock and his head was pushed to the ground. Youth A said he was lying on the
floor and Supervisor 1 kept pushing his head on the floor. This occurred inside the
bedroom. Youth A said that Supervisor 1 and Staff 4 picked him up from the floor
and took him to the kitchen where he sat by the sink. Youth A said his head was
bleeding and his knees were scraped.
4

Youth A said he was restrained again, but in the kitchen and noted that he thought
this lasted for about 30 minutes. Youth A said that he “flopped” to the ground and the
staff were holding his arms and legs. Youth A said that Supervisor 1, Staff 1, Staff 3,
and Staff 4 were all holding him in a face down position. Youth A said that he was
trying to get on his side during the restraint. Youth A said that Staff 4 was
intentionally putting pressure on Youth A’s carpet burned knees to make it hurt.
Youth A said the staff picked him up and he began pacing. Staff 1 picked Youth A up
and slammed him in a bear hug manner. Youth A said everyone was screaming and
staff circled around him. Youth A said that Staff 3 told him to stay put and that Youth
A could not leave the area. Youth A said he tried going under the kitchen table to get
out but Supervisor 1 grabbed Youth A by the foot and pulled him back from under
the table. Youth A said that he went to his room and took down his bed and began
punching it, so staff took his bed out. Youth A said he felt like staff were picking on
him.
Youth A said that Supervisor 1 talked to him in his bedroom and Youth A told
Supervisor 1 that he thinks Supervisor 1 hurt him on purpose. Youth A said
Supervisor 1 said that he understood and was talking like he was on Youth A’s side.
Youth A said that he tried to close his door but was not allowed so the staff took him
to the kitchen again, where Youth A was restrained again. Youth A said that there
was a vent nearby and he scraped his foot on it. He said he was wearing shorts and
no shirt or shoes. Youth A said that he thought Staff 4 was intentionally sweating on
Youth A. Youth A said that he was held by the wall and then released and asked for
a chair but was told no. Youth A said that he sat in the kitchen for a long period and
began getting “pissed” at the staff. He went back to his bedroom and Supervisor 1
put a chair in the doorway. Youth A said nothing else happened after that.
Youth A reported that his right arm was hurting while he was at Highfields, but was
from prior to placement there. Youth A said that he did not see the nurse but was
given alcohol and Band-Aids for the scrapes. Youth A said that when he went to the
emergency room, he did not mention his arm hurting. Youth A said this was his first
restraint with the involved staff. Youth A reviewed the injuries he said he obtained
during this incident. Youth A said he got the scrapes/rug burn on his left forehead
and upper cheek from when Supervisor 1 had him in a headlock and was pushing
Youth A’s head on the floor in his bedroom. Youth A said that the mark was from the
carpet. Youth A said that he had three marks on the left side of his neck but did not
know how those got there. Youth A said that he had carpet burn on his knees that
came from the restraints. Youth A said that he had a cut on the bottom of his right
foot from the vent in the kitchen. Youth A said that he had marks on both shoulders
but was not sure how he got them, but reported they were from the restraints. Youth
A said no other youth witnessed this incident as they were in bed.
I spoke with the Chief Administrator (CA) on 05/25/21 at the facility jointly with the
DHHS Specialist. The CA reported ongoing behavioral issues with Youth A that has
resulted in two to three staff working with him to maintain safety as Youth A
5

continues to make threats and be destructive. The worker has decided to move
Youth A to detention.
I reviewed the video of this incident jointly with the DHHS Specialist, and with the
assistance of the Manager. The video started about 22:32:16 and was a view from
the common area where Youth A was viewed. We changed from views of the
common area and the kitchen to review this incident from the best camera vantage
point. Staffs 1, 2, 3, and 4 were also in the area. About 22:37:30 Youth A came out
of his room and into the common area and was standing face to face with Supervisor
1. Supervisor 1 went hands on with Youth A, but it could not be seen why he
engaged from the camera angle. The pair fell to the floor with Youth A on top of
Supervisor 1. Staff 4 grabbed Youth A’s legs, while Staff 1 held Youth A’s left arm
and Staff 3 held Youth A’s right arm. Youth A was in a prone position. The Manager
referred to this as “emergency floor procedures” and said the staff are trained on it.
Staff 2 was seen observing this restraint. About two minutes passed and the staff
began releasing and assisted Youth A to stand. They escorted him to the kitchen.
Supervisor 1 and Staff 1 continued to hold Youth A in a standing hold and had him
bent over. Youth A appeared to struggle, and they all went to the floor about
22:40:46. Youth A was seen in a prone position and did not appear to be struggling.
He was released about three minutes later and assisted up to stand. Staff held him
and used the wall for support. About 22:49:18 the staff escorted Youth A to his
bedroom. At the doorway to Youth A’s room there was some kind of struggle
between Youth A and staff, but what occurred was not clearly observable. The staff
and Youth A went in the bedroom and the interaction could not be seen. Staff 2 was
seen at the doorway but not involved in the physical altercation.
The staff escorted Youth A back to the kitchen at about 22:53:19. As Youth A
passed the kitchen camera, the marks on his forehead and cheek were visible. The
staff held youth as they backed up to the wall for support. Supervisor 1 was seen on
his phone during this time. About 22:54:59, Youth A struggled and went to the floor
and was held in a prone position again. About 23:02:36, Youth A was released and
assisted up from the floor. He was prone the entire time on the floor. Youth A sat by
the wall and the staff maintained distance.
Youth A went back to his bedroom and staff were seen going in and out of the
bedroom and huddling around his doorway. Around 23:20:06, staff again escorted
Youth A to the kitchen. Youth A sat on the counter on his own until Youth A got up
and threw a speaker. Youth A was restrained again but kneeling on his knees and
then sat down this time. The staff released Youth A and continued to monitor him in
the kitchen. About 00:50:40 Youth A was observed getting agitated and then tried to
go under the kitchen table. Supervisor 1 pulled Youth A back by the leg and the staff
restrained Youth A again and in a prone position. Staff 2 was seen observing. About
00:54:50 Youth A was released, and he got up on his own. Youth A walked to his
bedroom and the staff remained by the door. About 01:10:40, the staff removed
more items from Youth A’s bedroom and then about a minute later there was a
scuffle and Youth A was escorted back to the kitchen. Youth A was released, but
6

about 01:24:39 the staff went hands on again with no apparent threat of harm. Youth
A sat down while the staff held his arms. The staff then picked him up to stand and
tried to escort Youth A, but Youth A struggled and lifted his legs up off the floor. Staff
continued to walk while lifting/carrying Youth A. The staff carried Youth A to the
common area and sat him on the floor. About 01:25:55, Supervisor 1, Staff 1 and
Staff 4 then picked up Youth A and carried him to his bedroom. They set his feet on
the floor, so he walked into his room.
I interviewed Supervisor 1 at the facility, on 05/25/21, jointly with the DHHS
Specialist. Supervisor 1 recounted the incident, noting that Youth A had been angry
after a phone call with his mother. Supervisor 1 said he tried to talk to Youth A, but
Youth A was not responsive and became increasingly verbally aggressive.
Supervisor 1 added that Youth A had previously been physically aggressive with
staff as well. Supervisor 1 said that Youth A approached, and shoulder bumped
Supervisor 1, so Supervisor 1 tried to put Youth A in a side hold, but Youth A
struggled and they went to the floor. The other staff assisted in holding Youth A in an
Emergency Floor Procedure. Supervisor 1 said that no restraints are designed to
happen on the floor, but they end up there sometimes. Then they helped Youth A up
to his feet and escorted him to his bedroom, where Youth A reportedly swung on
Supervisor 1. Supervisor 1 said he went in Youth A’s bedroom to get him in a Team
Control hold but ended up on the floor. Staff 1 and Staff 4 assisted and possibly Staff
3, per Supervisor 1. Supervisor 1 said that Youth A was struggling, biting, and
spitting during this restraint. The staff then got Youth A up and escorted him to the
kitchen because it was late and the other kids were asleep. Supervisor 1 said they
continued to try and deescalate Youth A, released him, and backed up to a safe
distance.
Youth A then went to his room and they allowed him some time to change with the
door closed, but when Youth A would not come out or open his door, Supervisor 1
said the staff went in and had to remove furniture as Youth A was throwing things
and being destructive. Supervisor 1 said at one point Youth A grabbed a pen and
threatened to stab staff. Supervisor 1 said that he thinks Youth A’s rug burn injuries
came from the restraint in the bedroom because “things got rough due to
resistance.” Supervisor 1 was not sure how the injuries occurred but noted that
Youth A was rubbing his face on the floor while struggling against the staff. When
they came out of the kitchen was when Supervisor 1 noticed the marks. Supervisor 1
said that the marks really bothered Youth A and “I don’t blame him.” Supervisor 1
said that he offered to help get Youth A cleaned up, but Youth A was resistant.
Supervisor 1 said that toward the end of this long incident, Youth A finally allowed
Supervisor 1 to help get his head cleaned up.
Supervisor 1 noted scratches on Youth A’s neck also, that he did not know how they
occurred. Supervisor 1 said that the cut on Youth A’s foot came from Youth A
pushing against the wall in the kitchen and he scratched it on the vent. Supervisor 1
said he is current on his restraint training and has not had any disciplinary action in
the last year. Supervisor 1 reported that they were not trying to take Youth A to a
7

prone restraint and got him up as soon as safely possible. Per Supervisor 1, the staff
do monitor the youth during restraints. Supervisor 1 said that picking up a youth
during an escort is not a taught procedure under the facility model. Supervisor 1 said
they decided to pick him up to get him back to his bedroom and then were able to
leave him alone. Supervisor 1 also acknowledged pulling Youth A by his leg out from
under the table and said he had “no excuse” for doing that. Supervisor 1 just wanted
to stop Youth A from trying to escape.
I interviewed Staff 1 on 05/25/21, at the facility, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
Staff 1 reviewed the incident with similar details as viewed during the video review.
Staff 1 said that this situation began after he allowed Youth A to make an after-hours
phone call to his family. Staff 1 said he allowed this due to Youth A having a recent
death in his family, but Supervisor 1 questioned Staff 1 on why he was allowing after
hours calls. Staff 1 said that when he explained this to Youth A, Youth A took
offense and began escalating and asked to speak to Supervisor 1. When Supervisor
1 came to the house Youth A got even more agitated. Staff 1 said that the staff tried
to support Youth A, but he continued to escalate and was not responsive. Staff 1
said that the first restraint started because Youth A pushed through and maybe tried
to hit Supervisor 1, but Staff 1 was not sure. Staff 1 said he thinks Youth A was
looking to fight Supervisor 1 the whole time. Staff 1 said that Youth A would
escalate, and they would put him in a Team Control. Youth A would deescalate and
then begin testing the staff and they would have to do it again. Staff 1 said that this
went on until about 3:00am. Staff 1 said that when Youth A dropped his weight
during the last escort to his bedroom, the staff did lift/carry Youth A. Staff 1
acknowledged that this is not an approved technique, but noted that they were trying
to avoid another restraint. When asked why Youth A was held prone in every
restraint, Staff 1 said that they get the youth up when it is safe to do so. They do not
intentionally take youth to the floor or have them in a prone position, but do if the
youth drops or momentum takes them there. Staff 1 also reported being in the
bedroom for the restraint when Youth A got the rug burn on his face. Staff 1 denied
seeing marks on Youth A’s neck or seeing any staff put Youth A in a headlock. Staff
1 was aware that Youth A cut his foot in the kitchen on the vent during a restraint.
I interviewed Staff 2 at the facility, on 05/25/21, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
Staff 2 said that she saw just about the entire incident, noting that Youth A calmed
down and talked with Supervisor 1 before she left around 2:15am. Staff 2 reviewed
the incident and confirmed Youth A initially escalated over the phone call and
blamed Supervisor 1. Staff 2 said that Youth A began threatening Supervisor 1.
When Supervisor 1 came to the house, Staff 2 said that the two were going back
and forth and Youth A swung at Supervisor 1, which lead to a restraint. Staff 1
recalled the staff escorting Youth A back to his bedroom where Youth A swung and
hit Supervisor 1 and was subsequently restrained again on the floor. Staff 1 said that
the staff and Youth A were “crammed” in the area where the restraint occurred and
that the staff tried to move out from the corner. Staff 1 said that she thinks that Youth
A rubbed his head on the floor during this restraint, but noted that she did not see or
think the staff rubbed Youth A’s head on the floor on purpose. Staff 1 said that she
8

offered to help Youth A clean his face up that night, but he would not let her. Youth A
only let her wipe his face, but not clean the scrape. He did allow her to help the next
day. Staff 2 did not see any injury to Youth A’s foot. Staff 2 said that the next day
Youth A showed her some scrapes/ carpet burn on his knees. Staff 2 denied
witnessing any staff use headlocks, put hands on Youth A’s neck, use excessive
force or intentionally hurt Youth A during any of the restraints. Staff 2 said that she
did not see staff carry Youth A or pick him up during a transport. Staff 2 said that she
did not feel staff instigated or picked on Youth A, but Staff 2 said that she thinks
Youth A took it that way. Staff 2 said she observed the restraints to make sure Youth
A was ok and that staff held appropriately, even when prone, until it was safe to
move him.
I interviewed Staff 3 on 05/25/21, at the facility, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
Staff 3 reviewed the incident noting the multiple restraints. Staff 3 said that he
responded to an emergency call and noted that the restraint was already occurring
when he arrived, but Staff 3 switched out with one of the staff. He could not recall
who. Staff 3 said that Youth A had become escalated several times and was
physically managed. Staff 3 said that Staff 1 left around midnight when Youth A was
still escalated but staff were giving him space. Regarding injuries, Staff 3 said that
Youth A had carpet burn on his face. Staff 3 said that he did not see it happen. Staff
3 said that Youth A complained of pressure on his arm, so Staff 1 adjusted his hold.
Staff 3 said that he and the other staff tried de-escalation strategies and put on
music and let Youth A go to his room, but nothing worked. Staff 3 said that they hold
youth until it is safe to move them, even if they are prone. Staff 3 said that he did not
observe any staff using a choke hold or putting their hands on Youth A’s neck.
I interviewed Youth A’s worker via phone on 06/07/21. The worker reported being
aware of this incident and expressed no concerns. The worker did not feel the staff
at the facility have acted inappropriately with Youth A, noting that Youth A
challenges authority. He reported that the facility keeps him up to date on issues and
concerns with regard to Youth A.
I interviewed Staff 4 via phone jointly with the DHHS Specialist on 06/10/21. Staff 4
recalled the incident and provided a recount that was very similar to those provided
by other staff. Staff 4 said Youth A was restrained in Youth A’s bedroom, in the
common area, and multiple times in the kitchen and noted he participated in most of
them. Staff 4 said that he did not participate in the restraint that occurred in the
bedroom but was present for it. Staff 4 said that the bedroom restraint occurred
because Youth A assaulted Supervisor 1. Staff 4 said that the staff initiated a Team
Control position and it went to the floor. Staff 4 said when on the floor it is an
Emergency Floor Procedure. Staff 4 said that the injuries to Youth A’s face occurred
during the bedroom restraint when he saw Youth A struggling against the staff and
rubbing his own head on the floor in the process. Staff 4 said that the prone
restraints are provided for in the restraint model, but the staff try to get the youth up
as soon as safely possible. During the restraints with Youth A, Staff 4 said that they
would attempt to get Youth A up, but Youth A was threatening, struggling, and
9

clenching, which made it unsafe. Staff 4 denied any memory of carrying Youth A,
only escorting him.
I interviewed the complainant, on 06/10/21, via phone. The allegations were
reviewed with the complainant. The complainant added that they know other friends
and family who were placed at the facility years ago and reported these kinds of
restraints happened then also. The complainant was concerned about the injuries to
Youth A and that she was not notified when the facility advised her of the restraint.
The complainant also reported that Youth A said that the staff antagonize the youth
to get the youth to act out. The complainant also expressed concern that a nurse did
not evaluate Youth A after the incident.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation is as follows:
 Employee disciplinary action and performance evaluations were reviewed for
the involved staff. Outside of minor attendance or unrelated issues the
following were observed: Supervisor 1 received a written reprimand, in
08.2019, for not calling for assistance in an escalating situation with a youth
until after physical management had begun, and not accurately and fully
explaining the incident on the incident report. Supervisor 1 received a written
reprimand, in 05.2019, for not calling for assistance in an escalating situation
with a youth until after physical management had begun, using unapproved
physical management technique, and not accurately and fully explaining the
incident on the incident report. Staff 3 received a Performance Feedback
memo, in 05.2017, related to active supervision.
 Behavior Management Philosophy and Procedures: The policy says that
physical management is not to be used for behavior management, but only if
there is an imminent threat of danger to an individual or significant and
dangerous property damage. ‘Emergency floor procedures are no longer
permitted based on the new emergency rules provided by the state.’ The
policy notes that if a restraint goes to the floor the staff are to do one of the
following, 1. Disengage, 2. Help the youth to their knees or to stand without
use of force, or 3. If the youth struggles while in an escort or hold, the staff
can use an approved hold that allows the youth to be seated.
 Critical Incident Procedures: Protocol to respond to critical incidents: ‘…it is
expected that staff members file factual, timely, and complete incident
reports.’
 Incident Report, dated 05/20/21, and authored by Staff 2. Report noted that
Supervisor 1 was on duty. The report outlined that Youth A became upset
when Supervisor 1 directed the staff that youth are not to make phone calls
after 10:00pm. Youth A became aggressive and required multiple restraints.
The rug burn on Youth A’s face was documented and it noted that he
declined any further assistance from staff. Supervisor 1 signed off on the
report as did the Manager.
 Emergency Department Record, dated 05/22/21. The report noted two
superficial forehead abrasions noted, scrape on foot and scraped left knee.
10

No other signs of serious secondary injury. Treat abrasions with topical
antibiotic.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
qualifications.
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
(b) Experience to perform the duties of the position
assigned.
ANALYSIS: The facility is compliant with this rule. There is no supporting
evidence that Supervisor 1 or other staff beat up Youth A. Youth
A was restrained multiple times and did sustain some superficial
injuries, which were assessed as such with no other medical
concerns noted by the treating physician, but there was no
evidence to support the allegation of staff assaulting Youth A.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Youth did not receive medical attention and did not attend school on 5/21/21 due to
the pain.
INVESTIGATION:
Youth A was observed with several marks on his body. This included
abrasions/carpet burns on his forehead and cheek, a small cut on his foot, red marks
on his neck, and carpet burn/scratches on his knees. Most notable was the carpet
burn on his face, which was scabbed when seen in person on 05/25/21. Youth A
said that staff gave him items to clean his injuries and Band-Aids as well. He further
reported going to the hospital for an evaluation of his injuries. Staff also reported
offering to assist Youth A in cleaning up his abrasions and providing him appropriate
cleaning items and Band-Aids as well.
The facility policy states that if an injury occurs that the Director will notify licensing.
This occurred on 05/24/21 when the Director contacted the assigned DCWL
Consultant about this incident and Youth A having been moved to detention.
11

APPLICABLE RULE
Rule 400.4142 Health services: policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
services policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
ANALYSIS: The facility is compliant with the rule as the injuries observed to
Youth A appeared to be, and were assessed to be, superficial
and not in need of immediate professional medical care. Staff
did offer basic first aid. The facility did have the youth medically
evaluated; however, it was two days later and only after the
DHHS Specialist requested it.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It is highly recommended that the facility adds to their policy that
all observed/reported injuries, even minor, will be professionally
evaluated at the facility by medical personnel, or as soon as it is
safe to transport the youth, if they are sustained during a
restraint.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
The staff did not follow the physical management policy.
INVESTIGATION:
During the course of this investigation, the staff were viewed on camera review, to
have restrained Youth A multiple times over a few hours. Not all of the incidents of
restraint were found to have a clear observation of an imminent risk of harm, and
they were done in a prohibited (prone) position. The facility policy says that physical
management is not to be used for behavior management, but only if there is an
imminent threat of danger to an individual or significant and dangerous property
damage. This was not always observed in the video review. Additionally, the staff did
not disengage, or appear to make attempts to quickly move Youth A to a supine
position, or to stand him up at the earliest opportunity. The facility policy notes that,
‘Emergency floor procedures are no longer permitted based on the new emergency
rules provided by the state.’ The staff did not adhere to this. Finally, the staff were
observed to use other techniques that are not approved (carrying Youth A during the
escort, pulling Youth A by the leg from under the table) in the facility’s restraint
model, and this was acknowledged by staff.
12

APPLICABLE RULE
Rule 1 Prohibition of Prone Restraint; Procedures Involving Other
Restraints in Child Caring Institutions
(1) A child caring institution (CCI) must establish and follow
written policies and procedures regarding restraint. These
policies and procedures shall be available to all residents,
their families, and referring agencies.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation of the rule as they did not follow their
policies and procedures related to physical management.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2021C0214007, 03/11/21 and CAP, 03/15/21 (cited for not
following restraint policies but under Rule 1(2).
2019C0212028, 08/14/19 and CAP, 08/19/19 (cited under R
159(1))
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
The facility did not accurately report the events of this incident on the incident report.
INVESTIGATION:
During the course of this investigation, it was found that the Incident Report,
submitted by Supervisor 1, was not an accurate reflection of the incident as it
omitted the staff holding Youth A in a prone position multiple times, lifting/carrying
Youth A, and pulling Youth A by his leg from under the kitchen table.
13

APPLICABLE RULE
Rule 2 The written policy must include all of the following:
(c) Procedures for recording restraints as an incident
report. The incident report must include the reason for the
restraint, the type of restraint used and its duration, names
of all staff involved with the restraint and their roles and a
description of all less restrictive interventions utilized prior
to the initiation of the restraint.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation of the rule, as the incident report was a
brief summary of the hours long incident but did not identify the
staff holding Youth A in a prone position multiple times,
lifting/carrying Youth A, or pulling Youth A by his leg from under
the kitchen table. Supervisor 1 signed off on the incident report,
which was authored by Staff 2 who observed most of the
incident, and was also reviewed by the Manager, who had also
reviewed the video. The facility’s policy calls for staff to file
factual, timely, and complete incident reports.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the facility submitting an
acceptable corrective action plan for the noted violations.
